text.__SUMMARY__: Astragalus preussii (common name - Preuss’ milkvetch) is an annual or perennial plant in the legume family (Fabaceae) found in the Colorado Plateau and Canyonlands region of the southwestern United States.
text.Description-Growth pattern: It is an annual or perennial plant from 4 to 15 inches (10 to 38 cm) tall, growing upright from a woody base.
text.Description-Leaves and stems: It has compound pinnate leaves from 1 1⁄2 to 15 inches (3.8 to 38.1 cm) long, with 7-25 3⁄4 inch (1.9 cm), elliptic leaflets.
text.Description-Inflorescence and fruit:
It blooms from March to June. The inflorescence has 3-22 flowers per stalk, with a small, green, 5-lobed  calyx  around a tubular set of white to pink to purple petals, 3⁄4 inch (1.9 cm) long. 
When dried, 3⁄4 inch (1.9 cm) seed pods are papery or leathery, elliptical, and are either smooth or covered with soft hairs.
text.Habitat and range: It only grows in soils containing Selenium.
text.Ecological and human interactions:
It is named after Charles Preuss.
